Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at two unread messages. My mom had texted, “Can we talk tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I knew she wanted me to check in, to be the daughter who listens and reassures, who asks if everything is okay at home. But my phone buzzed again—this time, it was from my boyfriend. “We need to talk about the bills. I can’t keep arguing like this.” My heart tightened. We’d fought three times this week about money, and I knew he expected me to help fix things, to be the understanding girlfriend who could smooth things over. I felt pulled in two directions, both needing me to be their anchor. I wanted to be there for my parents, to offer comfort, but I also needed to resolve things with him before the tension grew worse. My fingers hovered over the screen, torn between calling my mom or replying to him first, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in.
